subject: officer
definition: In English law. An officer in the royal household who has jurisdiction and cognizance of offenses committed within the household and verge, and BL.LAW DICT.(2D ED.)

name: kluge
subject: something
definition: Something assembled from whatever was available to ‘make do’, but not built according to design or plan.

name: kirk
subject: church church
definition: In Scotch law. A church; the church; the established church of Scotland.

name: under and subject
subject: grantee
definition: Words frequently used in conveyances of land which is subject to a mortgage, to show that the grantee takes subject to such mortgage. See Walker v. I’hysick. 5 Pa. 203; Moore’s Appeal, 88 Pa. 453, 32 Am. Rep. 400; Blood v. Crow Livick Co., 171 I’a. 328, 33 Atl. 344; Lavelle v. Gordon, 15 Mont. 515, 39 l’ac. 740.

name: under and subject
subject: grantee
definition: Words frequently used in conveyances of land which is subject to a mortgage, to show that the grantee takes subject to such mortgage. See Walker v. I’hysick. 5 Pa. 203; Moore’s Appeal, 88 Pa. 453, 32 Am. Rep. 400; Blood v. Crow Livick Co., 171 I’a. 328, 33 Atl. 344; Lavelle v. Gordon, 15 Mont. 515, 39 l’ac. 740.

name: uncontestable clause
subject: insurer
definition: a clause in a life insurance policy that means the insurer cannot contest a claim if a policy has been in force for a set period of time.

name: unconscious minors
subject: physician
definition: a medical term in law that lets a physician treat an unconscious child without consent of there is no on available to give consent.

name: unconscious adults
subject: physician
definition: a medical term in law that lets a physician treat an unconscious person without consent of there is no on available to give consent.

name: unconscionable conduct
subject: phrase
definition: This phrase describes conduct that is unbelievable bad, is outrageous and display the lack of conscience.

name: valuer
subject: person business
definition: A person whose business is to appraise or set a value upon property.

name: valuer
subject: person business
definition: A person whose business is to appraise or set a value upon property.

name: valued policy
subject: valued parties
definition: A policy Is called “valued,” when the parties, having agreed upon the value of the interest insured, in order to save the necessity of further proof have inserted the valuation In the policy, in the nature of liquidated damages. 1 Duer, Ins. 97.

name: warrant in bankruptcy
subject: order
definition: an order from a court to a marshal that directs him to take possession of property from a person or company who has been declared bankrupt.

name: warning,
subject: notice
definition: under the old practice of the English court of probate, was a notice given by a registrar of the principal registry to a person who had entered a caveat, warning him, within six days after service, to enter an appearance to the caveat in the principal registry, and to set forth his interest, concluding with a notice that in default of his doing so the court would proceed to do all such acts, matters, and things as should be necessary. By the rules under the judicature acts, a writ of summons has been substituted for a warning. Sweet.

name: warehousing
subject: warehouse
definition: Holding assets in conduit for them to be repackaged for securitization. The warehouse takes on the risk. Or taking on risk for assets before a sale.

name: warehouse-keeper’s liability
subject: keeper
definition: A keeper of a warehouse has the obligation and duty to take care of stored goods and to return them within contract terms. Also known as warehouseman’s liability.

name: warehouse-keeper’s liability
subject: keeper
definition: A keeper of a warehouse has the obligation and duty to take care of stored goods and to return them within contract terms. Also known as warehouseman’s liability.

name: absorbed overhead
subject: applied overhead
definition: Applied overhead is a definition that will be helpful here.

name: absolute sale
subject: payment
definition: When an agreed payment is made the property is considered transferred from the seller to the buyer. This payment has no stipulations in this simple transaction.

name: absolute privilege
subject: qualified privilege
definition: A rule that protects the holder from harm that occurs from any actions or lack there of. Qualified privilege is another term for this.

name: baggage
subject: term
definition: In the law of carriers. This term comprises such articles of personal convenience or necessity as are usually carried by passengers for their personal use, and not merchandise or other valuables, although carried in the trunks of passengers, which are not designed for any such use, but for other purposes, such as a sale and the like. The term includes whatever the passenger takes with him for his personal use or convenience according to the habits or wants of the particular class to which he belongs, either with reference to the immediate necessities or ultimate purpose of the journey. Macrow v. Railway Co., L. R. 6 Q. B. 612; Bomar v. Maxwell, 9 Humph. (Tenn.) 621, 51 Am. Dec. 6S2; Railroad Co. v. Collins, 56 111. 217; Hawkins v. Hoffman, 6 Hill (N. Y.) 590, 41 Am. Dec. 767; Mauritz v. Railroad Co. (C. C.) 23 Fed. 771; Dexter v. Railroad Co., 42 N. Y. 326, 1 Am. Rep. 527; Story, Bailm.

name: bag holder
subject: investor
definition: An investor who keeps stocks until they are basically worthless.

name: badwill
subject: company
definition: When a company has a bad business practice that investors find out about. Revenue is lost as well as investors, customers, and suppliers. The market value also goes down. This can also be tried in court.

name: badger
subject: one
definition: In old English law. One who made a practice of buying corn or victuals in one place, and carrying them to another to sell and make profit by them.

name: transaction
subject: transaction
definition: In the civil law. A transaction or compromise is an agreement between two or more persons, who, for preventing or putting an end to a lawsuit, adjust their differences by mutual consent, in the manner which they agree on, and which every one of them prefers to the hope of gaining, balanced by the danger of losing. This contract must be reduced into writing. Civ. Code La. art. 3071. In common law. Whatever may be done by one person which affects another’s rights, and out of which a cause of action may arise. Scarborough v. Smith, 18 Kan. 406. “Transaction” is a broader term than “contract.” A contract is a transaction, but a transaction is not necessarily a contract. See Ter Kuile v. Marsland, 81 Ilun, 420, 31 N. Y. Supp. 5; Xenia Branch Bank v. Lee, 7 Abb. Prac. (N. Y.) 372; Roberts v. Donovan, 70 Cal. 113, 11 Pac. 599. TRANSCRIPT 1167 TRANSIEN

name: transaction
subject: compromise
definition: In the civil law. A transaction or compromise is an agreement between two or more persons, who, for preventing or putting an end to a lawsuit, adjust their differences by mutual consent, in the manner which they agree on, and which every one of them prefers to the hope of gaining, balanced by the danger of losing. This contract must be reduced into writing. Civ. Code La. art. 3071. In common law. Whatever may be done by one person which affects another’s rights, and out of which a cause of action may arise. Scarborough v. Smith, 18 Kan. 406. “Transaction” is a broader term than “contract.” A contract is a transaction, but a transaction is not necessarily a contract. See Ter Kuile v. Marsland, 81 Ilun, 420, 31 N. Y. Supp. 5; Xenia Branch Bank v. Lee, 7 Abb. Prac. (N. Y.) 372; Roberts v. Donovan, 70 Cal. 113, 11 Pac. 599. TRANSCRIPT 1167 TRANSIEN

name: badge
subject: mark
definition: A mark or cognizance worn to show the relation of the wearer to any person or thing; the token of anything; a distinctive mark of office or service.

name: badge
subject: cognizance
definition: A mark or cognizance worn to show the relation of the wearer to any person or thing; the token of anything; a distinctive mark of office or service.

name: bad faith cause of action
subject: party conduct
definition: a law suit that is based on an assumption that the opposing parties conduct showed reckless disregard of the suitor’s right and was unreasonable.

name: calling the jury
subject: just cause
definition: Successively drawing out of a box into which they have been previously put the names of the jurors on the panels annexed to the nisi prius record, and calling them over in the order in which they are so drawn. The twelve persons whose names are first called, and who appear, are sworn as the jury, unless some just cause of challenge or excuse, with respect to any of them, shall be brought forward.

name: calling party pays (cpp)
subject: billing system
definition: A billing method in which a wireless phone caller pays only for making calls and not for receiving them. The standard American billing system requires wireless phone customers to pay for all calls made and received on a wireless phone.

name: called up share capital
subject: value
definition: The value of unpaid (but issued shares) which a company has requested payment for.

name: called up share capital
subject: which company
definition: The value of unpaid (but issued shares) which a company has requested payment for.

name: callable bond
subject: callable bond
definition: A callable bond (also called redeemable bond) is a type of bond (debt security) that allows the issuer of the bond to retain the privilege of redeeming the bond at some point before the bond reaches the date of maturity.

name: callable bond
subject: bond
definition: A callable bond (also called redeemable bond) is a type of bond (debt security) that allows the issuer of the bond to retain the privilege of redeeming the bond at some point before the bond reaches the date of maturity.

name: call to action
subject: call to action
definition: Call to Action (CTA) is an organization that advocates for a variety of liberal causes to change the Catholic Church.

name: data bank
subject: diary
definition: A collection of data on a subject or saved for a purpose. A diary or file is data bank.

name: data bank
subject: file
definition: A collection of data on a subject or saved for a purpose. A diary or file is data bank.

name: data access time
subject: time computer
definition: The time a computer takes to respond to a request the user makes. The time depends on where the data is kept. Refer to data transfer rate.

name: dash to trash
subject: investor
definition: When investors buy stocks and bonds with a low price to get into a market during the bull market.

name: dash to trash
subject: investor
definition: When investors buy stocks and bonds with a low price to get into a market during the bull market.

name: efficiency ratio
subject: measurement
definition: The measurement of how well a company manages profit versus costs. Accounts receivable and payable are the source for this measuring.

name: efficiency principle
subject: maximum social benefit
definition: An economic theory that states that the maximum social benefit that is received from any type of action is received when the marginal social costs of resource allocation is equal to the benefits from such an allocation of resources. Lays the groundwork on how critical business decisions regarding resource allocation are made.

name: efficiency engineer
subject: level individual
definition: Person accountable for the cycle of improving the effectiveness of machinery and personnel through analysis and application. Often a management level individual holds this responsibility.

name: effectiveness
subject: effectiveness
definition: The closeness of actual results achieved to meeting expectations. Effectiveness ignores expenditure, while efficiency measure worth of results. Efficiency is weighing results against costs over time, and effectiveness is weighing results against expectations over time.

name: effective stock
subject: total
definition: Total of ordered, though not yet received physical inventory and replenishments.

name: effective stock
subject: total
definition: Total of ordered, though not yet received physical inventory and replenishments.

name: premium loading
subject: amount insurer
definition: The amount an insurer needs to cover its expenses and generate profit. Fair premium is determined using premium loading and pure premium.

name: pure premium
subject: amount insurer
definition: The amount an insurer needs to cover their expenses. Along with premium loading it is used to calculate fair premium. Refer to expense loading.

name: fair premium
subject: methodology premium
definition: An INSURANCE pricing methodology where the PREMIUM charged an INSURED is intended to cover EXPECTED LOSSES and operating and administrative expenses, and provide an equitable return to providers of CAPITAL. Fair premium is comprised of PURE PREMIUM and PREMIUM LOADING (which also includes EXPENSE LOADING). Also known as GROSS RATE.

name: fair premium
subject: methodology premium
definition: An INSURANCE pricing methodology where the PREMIUM charged an INSURED is intended to cover EXPECTED LOSSES and operating and administrative expenses, and provide an equitable return to providers of CAPITAL. Fair premium is comprised of PURE PREMIUM and PREMIUM LOADING (which also includes EXPENSE LOADING). Also known as GROSS RATE.

name: fair market purchase option
subject: renter
definition: When a renter can buy the property at the end of the lease at market value. It is added to an rent to own lease.

name: gavel
subject: rent payment
definition: In English law. Custom; tribute; toll; yearly rent; payment of revenue; ofwhich there were anciently several sorts; as gavel-corn, gavel-malt, oat-gavcl, gavelfodder,etc. Termes de la Ley; Cowell; Co. Litt. 142a.

name: gavel
subject: ofwhich
definition: In English law. Custom; tribute; toll; yearly rent; payment of revenue; ofwhich there were anciently several sorts; as gavel-corn, gavel-malt, oat-gavcl, gavelfodder,etc. Termes de la Ley; Cowell; Co. Litt. 142a.

name: gastroenteritis
subject: general symptoms
definition: Inflammation of the stomach and the intestines. General symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Typical cause is varied. Also caused by lactose intolerance. Some common causes are bacteria or virus infestation, food poisoning, or eating contaminated food.

name: gastroenteritis
subject: general symptoms
definition: Inflammation of the stomach and the intestines. General symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Typical cause is varied. Also caused by lactose intolerance. Some common causes are bacteria or virus infestation, food poisoning, or eating contaminated food.

name: gasohol
subject: ethanol source
definition: Mixture of nine parts of unleaded gasoline by volume with one part of ethanol, ethyl alcohol. Ethanol source is fermented agricultural produce, typically corn. ‘Gasohol’ is a registered trademark of the Nebraska Gasohol Committee. It allows free use for blends with only ethanol, no other alcohol. The octane of gasohol is nearly that of gasoline, but it produces a cleaner emission, lower in carbon oxides.

name: judgment creditor
subject: one
definition: One who has obtained a judgment against his debtor, under which he can enforce execution. King y. Eraser, 23 S. C. 548; Baxter y. Moses, 77 Me. 405, 1 Atl. 350. 52 Am. Rep. 783; Code Civ. Proc. N. Y. 1899,

name: judgment conditional
subject: one
definition: the term used when a decision is rendered as long as one of the parties carries out certain actions.

name: impairment of memory
subject: term person
definition: A term where a person has the inability to remember events.

name: immunity
subject: which law
definition: An exemption from serving in an office, or performing duties which the law generally requires other citizens to perform. Long v. Converse, 91 U. S. 113, 23 LEd. 233; Ex parte Levy, 43 Ark. 54, 51 Am. Rep. 550; Lomas v. State, 3 Heisk. (Tenn.)30G; Douglass v. Stephens, 1 Del. Ch. 470.

name: demand curve
subject: price
definition: The curve sloping downward to the right that shows quantity of a product demanded at the different prices. The price is the verticle and the quantity is the horizontal axis. All other elements are assumed to be the same. It is used to get the equlibrium p

name: demand curve
subject: price
definition: The curve sloping downward to the right that shows quantity of a product demanded at the different prices. The price is the verticle and the quantity is the horizontal axis. All other elements are assumed to be the same. It is used to get the equlibrium p

name: kinked demand curve
subject: business
definition: Standard demand curve with a bend depicting competitors decreasing prices to match another’s, yet not raising prices to match another’s. Concern is that raising prices lose customers, so that once a business has reduced prices to a certain level, gain market share.

name: kingdom
subject: country officer
definition: A country where an officer called a “king” exercises the powers of gov- ernment, whether the same be absolute or limited. Wolff, Inst. Nat.

name: king’s remembrancer
subject: administrative changes
definition: An officer of the central ofiice of the English supreme court. Formerly he was an officer of the exchequer, and had important duties to perform In protecting the rights of the crown; e. g., by instituting proceedings for the recovery of land by writs of intrusion, (q. v.,) and for the recovery of legacy and succession duties; but of late years administrative changes have lessened the duties of the office. Sweet

name: king’s evidence
subject: one
definition: When several persons are charged with a crime, and one of them gives evidence against liis accomplices, on the promise of being granted a pardon, he is said to be admitted kiug’s or (in America) state’s evidence. 4 Steph. Comm. 305; Sweet.

name: king’s coroner and attorney
subject: officer
definition: An officer of the court of king’s bench, usually called “the master of the crown office,” whose duty it is to tile informations at the suit of a private subject by direction of the court. 4 Bl. Comm. 308, 300 ; 4 Steph. Comm. 374, 378.

name: king’s bench
subject: supreme court
definition: The supreme court of common law in England, being so called be- cause the king used formerly to sit there in person, the style of the court being “coram ipso rege.” It was called the “queen’s bench” in the reign of a queen, and during the protectorate of Cromwell it was styled the “up KING’S CHAMBERS 688

name: king’s bench
subject: england
definition: The supreme court of common law in England, being so called be- cause the king used formerly to sit there in person, the style of the court being “coram ipso rege.” It was called the “queen’s bench” in the reign of a queen, and during the protectorate of Cromwell it was styled the “up KING’S CHAMBERS 688

name: king’s advocate
subject: english advocate
definition: An English advocate who holds, in the courts in which the rules of the canon and civil law prevail, a similar position to that which the attorney general holds in the ordinary courts, t. e., he acts as counsel for the crown in ecclesiastical, admiralty, and probate cases, and advises the crown on questions of international law. In order of precedence it seems that he ranks after the attorney general. 3 Steph. Comm. 275n.

name: king
subject: woman
definition: The sovereign, ruler, or chief executive magistrate of a state or nation whose constitution is of the kind called “monarchical” is thus named if a man; if it be a woman, she is called “queen.” The word expresses the idea of one who rules singly over a whole people or has the highest executive power; but the office may be either hereditary or elective, and the sovereignty of the king may or may not be absolute, according to the constitution of the country.

name: king
subject: word
definition: The sovereign, ruler, or chief executive magistrate of a state or nation whose constitution is of the kind called “monarchical” is thus named if a man; if it be a woman, she is called “queen.” The word expresses the idea of one who rules singly over a whole people or has the highest executive power; but the office may be either hereditary or elective, and the sovereignty of the king may or may not be absolute, according to the constitution of the country.

name: king
subject: word
definition: The sovereign, ruler, or chief executive magistrate of a state or nation whose constitution is of the kind called “monarchical” is thus named if a man; if it be a woman, she is called “queen.” The word expresses the idea of one who rules singly over a whole people or has the highest executive power; but the office may be either hereditary or elective, and the sovereignty of the king may or may not be absolute, according to the constitution of the country.

name: unconscionability doctrine
subject: conditions of contract
definition: Legal principle where a court will modify or nullify conditions of contract placing one party at the other’s mercy.

name: value line composite index
subject: stock
definition: Index of 1700 stocks traded on NASDAQ, AMEX and NYSE stock markets. Stocks are raked on projected price performance and volatility of behavior.

name: value line composite index
subject: stock
definition: Index of 1700 stocks traded on NASDAQ, AMEX and NYSE stock markets. Stocks are raked on projected price performance and volatility of behavior.

name: value for money audit
subject: independent audit
definition: Independent audit of a non-profit organization to determine it is using its money efficiently and effectively. Also known as value for money analysis.

name: value fair
subject: seller
definition: the value that a seller will sell an item for a and a value the buyer is willing to pay.

name: absolute or conditional conveyance
subject: right
definition: right or property in a thing is transferred, free of any condition or qualification, by which it might be defeated or changed; as an ordinary deed of lands, in contradistinction to a mortgage, which is a condilional conveyance. Bur- rill; Falconer v. Buffalo, etc., R. Co., 69 N. Y. 491

name: absolute or conditional conveyance
subject: property
definition: right or property in a thing is transferred, free of any condition or qualification, by which it might be defeated or changed; as an ordinary deed of lands, in contradistinction to a mortgage, which is a condilional conveyance. Bur- rill; Falconer v. Buffalo, etc., R. Co., 69 N. Y. 491

name: absolute estate
subject: land real estate
definition: Any land, real estate or building that the owner has total control over, possession of and the right to disposal.

name: absolute estate
subject: building
definition: Any land, real estate or building that the owner has total control over, possession of and the right to disposal.

name: absolute auction
subject: auction
definition: An auction that has no reserve and where the highest bidder receives the item being sold.

name: absolute assignment
subject: collateral assignment
definition: A transfer between two parties where all benefits are exchanged without any stipulations. Collateral assignment is another term for this.

name: absolute advantage
subject: country
definition: A country who can more efficiently generate a good or service than another. This is a big advantage in business. This theory was first suggested by the UK economist Adam Smith as an extension of his division of labor doctrine. Other terms that might help are absolute cost advantage and competitive advantage.

name: absolute advantage
subject: country
definition: A country who can more efficiently generate a good or service than another. This is a big advantage in business. This theory was first suggested by the UK economist Adam Smith as an extension of his division of labor doctrine. Other terms that might help are absolute cost advantage and competitive advantage.

name: baculus
subject: his appearance
definition: A rod, staff, or wand, used in old English practice in making livery of seisin where no building stood on the land, (Bract. 40;) a stick or wand, by the erection of which on the land involved In a real action the defendant was summoned to put in his appearance; this was called “baculus nuntiatorius.” 3 Bl. Comm. 279.

name: backward integration
subject: consumer
definition: When the consumer of materials buys suppliers or makes their own to cut costs.

name: backup withholding
subject: investor
definition: Funds helo from an investment to cover taxes. It is used when the investor has no valid social security number with the IRS.

name: call report
subject: institution
definition: All regulated financial institutions in the United States are required to file periodic financial and other information with their respective regulators and other parties. For banks in the U.S.

name: call privilege
subject: deal
definition: When dealing with securities trading, an issuer of a bond indenture gives the issuer the right to revoke or redeem outstanding bonds with a certain price on a specific call date.

name: call privilege
subject: deal
definition: When dealing with securities trading, an issuer of a bond indenture gives the issuer the right to revoke or redeem outstanding bonds with a certain price on a specific call date.

name: call on a put
subject: option
definition: A COMPOUND OPTION that grants the buyer the right to purchase an underlying PUT OPTION from the seller of the compound. The option is generally purchased when the need for the underlying option is still uncertain. See also CALL ON A CALL, PUT ON A CALL, PUT ON A PUT.

name: call on a call
subject: option
definition: A COMPOUND OPTION that grants the buyer the right to purchase an underlying CALL OPTION from the seller of the compound. The option is generally purchased when the need for the underlying option is still uncertain. See also CALL ON A PUT, PUT ON A CALL, PUT ON A PUT.

name: call number
subject: library classification
definition: A library classification is a system of coding and organizing library materials (books, serials, audiovisual materials, computer files, maps, manuscripts, realia) according to their subject and allocating a call number to that information resource.

name: call money market
subject: broker
definition: Market in which brokers and dealers borrow money to satisfy their credit needs, either to finance their own inventory of securities or to cover their customers’ margin accounts.

name: call money market
subject: dealer
definition: Market in which brokers and dealers borrow money to satisfy their credit needs, either to finance their own inventory of securities or to cover their customers’ margin accounts.

name: dangerous instrumentality
subject: something
definition: When something causes damage or death without human interaction or guidance.

name: dangerous instrumentality
subject: something
definition: When something causes damage or death without human interaction or guidance.

name: effective franchise
subject: term
definition: The term applying to the rights a citizen has to vote when an election is called.

name: effective competition
subject: more than one person
definition: Condition where more than one person or company seek a unique piece of business with no collusion.

name: effective competition
subject: company
definition: Condition where more than one person or company seek a unique piece of business with no collusion.

name: effective annual return
subject: interest
definition: Interest compounded in an account for a full year for monies that stay there for the year earn additional funds for savings or time deposit.

name: fair access to insurance requirements plan (fair)
subject: property woner
definition: A plan the government that a property woner can’t get property insurance and has to go to a FAIR plan insurer.

name: faint (or feigned) action
subject: word
definition: In old English practice. An action was so called where the party bringing it had no title torecover, although the words of the writ were true; a false action was properly wherethe words of the writ were false. Litt.

name: failure to meet obligations
subject: tom
definition: This term applies to bank that fails to pay the depositor’s when they want there money and the failing of a person tom meet his obligations.

name: failure of consideration
subject: contract party
definition: When a contract party fails to do what they agreed to. The other party as to get restitution and make a claim.

name: gas guzzler tax
subject: fuel efficiency
definition: Tax on vehicle total purchase price if fuel efficiency is less than 22.5 miles per gallon. Typically paid by the automobile manufacturer or importing dealership. Likely passed on to the buyer somehow. National Energy Act initiated this tax.

name: garroting
subject: form
definition: A method of inflicting the death penalty on convicted criminals practisedin Spain, Portugal, and some Spanish- American countries, consisting in strangulationby means of an iron collar which is mechanically tightened about the neck of thesufferer, sometimes with the variation that a sharpened screw is made to advance fromthe back of the apparatus and pierce the base of the brain. Also, popularly, any form ofstrangling resorted to to overcome resistance or induce unconsciousness, especially asa concomitant to highway robbery.

name: garnishment payable
subject: employee
definition: Legal action requiring a company to record an involved employee’s wages even if the employee received no wages.

name: garnishee
subject: one garnished person
definition: One garnished; a person against whom process of garnishment isIssued; one who has money or property In his possession belonging to a defendant, orwho owes the defendant a debt, which money, property, or debt is attached iu bishands, with notice to him not to deliver or pay it over until the result of the suit beascertained. Welsh v. Blackwell. 14 N. J. Law, 348; Smith v. Miln, 22 Fed. Cas. 000.

name: garnishee
subject: one garnished person
definition: One garnished; a person against whom process of garnishment isIssued; one who has money or property In his possession belonging to a defendant, orwho owes the defendant a debt, which money, property, or debt is attached iu bishands, with notice to him not to deliver or pay it over until the result of the suit beascertained. Welsh v. Blackwell. 14 N. J. Law, 348; Smith v. Miln, 22 Fed. Cas. 000.

name: garnishee
subject: belonging to defendant
definition: One garnished; a person against whom process of garnishment isIssued; one who has money or property In his possession belonging to a defendant, orwho owes the defendant a debt, which money, property, or debt is attached iu bishands, with notice to him not to deliver or pay it over until the result of the suit beascertained. Welsh v. Blackwell. 14 N. J. Law, 348; Smith v. Miln, 22 Fed. Cas. 000.

name: garnishee
subject: orwho
definition: One garnished; a person against whom process of garnishment isIssued; one who has money or property In his possession belonging to a defendant, orwho owes the defendant a debt, which money, property, or debt is attached iu bishands, with notice to him not to deliver or pay it over until the result of the suit beascertained. Welsh v. Blackwell. 14 N. J. Law, 348; Smith v. Miln, 22 Fed. Cas. 000.

name: garman kohlhagen model
subject: interest rate
definition: Foreign exchange’s European call option value estimating formula. Risk-free interest rate paid on foreign currency is a continuous dividend yield in this formula. Borrowing and lending takes place at the same interest rate is foundational to the contrast of this Black Scholes option pricing model’s assumption.

name: journey
subject: original signification
definition: The original signification of this word was a day’s travel. It is now applied to a travel by land from place to place, without restriction of time. But, when thus applied, It is employed to designate a travel which is without the ordinary habits, busi- ness, or duties of the person, to a distance from his home, and beyond the circle of his friends or acquaintances. Gholson v. State, 53 Ala. 521, 25 Am. Rep. G52.

name: journal voucher
subject: defined requirements
definition: Every financial transaction hat meets defined requirements has this prepared, written authorization.

name: journal
subject: book
definition: A daily book; a book in which entries are made or events recorded from day to day. In maritime law, the journal (otherwise called “log” or “log-book”) is a book kept on every vessel, which contains a brief record of the events and occurrences of each day of a voyage, with the nautical observations, course of the ship, account of (he weather, etc. In the system of double- entry book-keeping, the journal is an account- book into which are transcribed, daily or at other Intervals, the items entered upon the day-book, for more convenient posting into the ledger. In the usage of legislative bodies, the journal is a daily record of the proceedings of either house. It is kept by the clerk, and in it are entered the appointments and actions of committees, introduction of bills, motions, votes, resolutions, etc., in the order of their occurrence. See Oakland Pav. Co. v. Hilton, G9 Cal. 479, 11 Pac. 3; Montgomery Beer Bottling Works v. Gaston, 120 Ala. 425, 28 Soutl> 497. 51 L R. A. 390. 85 Am. St. Rep. 42; Martin v. Com., 107 Pa. 190

name: jointure
subject: freehold estate
definition: A freehold estate in lands or tenements secured to the wife, and to take effect on the decease of the husband, and to continue during her life at the least, unless she be herself the cause of its determination. Vance v. Vance, 21 Me. 369.     A competent livelihood of freehold for the wife of lands and tenements to take effect presently in possession or profit, after the decease of the husband, for the life of the wife at least. Co. Litt. 3Gb; 2 Rl. Comm. 137. See Fellers v. Fellers, 54 Neb. 094, 74 N. W. 1077; Saunders v. Saunders, 144 Mo. 4S2, 40 S. W. 428; Graham v. Graham, G7 Hun, 320, 22 N. Y. Supp. 299.     A jointure strictly signifies a joint estate limited to both husband and wife, and such was its original form; but, in its more usual form, it is a sole estate limited to the wife only, expectant upon a life-estate In the husband. 2 Bl. Comm. 137; 1 Steph. Comm. 255.

name: jointure
subject: to take
definition: A freehold estate in lands or tenements secured to the wife, and to take effect on the decease of the husband, and to continue during her life at the least, unless she be herself the cause of its determination. Vance v. Vance, 21 Me. 369.     A competent livelihood of freehold for the wife of lands and tenements to take effect presently in possession or profit, after the decease of the husband, for the life of the wife at least. Co. Litt. 3Gb; 2 Rl. Comm. 137. See Fellers v. Fellers, 54 Neb. 094, 74 N. W. 1077; Saunders v. Saunders, 144 Mo. 4S2, 40 S. W. 428; Graham v. Graham, G7 Hun, 320, 22 N. Y. Supp. 299.     A jointure strictly signifies a joint estate limited to both husband and wife, and such was its original form; but, in its more usual form, it is a sole estate limited to the wife only, expectant upon a life-estate In the husband. 2 Bl. Comm. 137; 1 Steph. Comm. 255.

name: jointress, jointuress
subject: woman
definition: A woman who has an estate settled on her by her hus- band, to hold during her life, if she survive him. Co. Litt. 46.

name: jointly-owned property
subject: two or more owners
definition: Two or more owners having property in their names.

name: jointly and severally
subject: loan balance
definition: A full loan balance is a liability to the signatories as a group or from each of them individually, with enough free assets to satisfy the lender’s claim. The lender may sue any signatory, and has the freedom to claim against one without taking any action against the others. Term used commonly in loan agreements involving two or more borrowers not necessarily on a proportional or prorata basis. Also refer to joint liability.

name: jointly and severally
subject: lender
definition: A full loan balance is a liability to the signatories as a group or from each of them individually, with enough free assets to satisfy the lender’s claim. The lender may sue any signatory, and has the freedom to claim against one without taking any action against the others. Term used commonly in loan agreements involving two or more borrowers not necessarily on a proportional or prorata basis. Also refer to joint liability.

name: immigrant
subject: person
definition: This term describes a person who enters a country for permanent residence from another country.

name: immaterial and irrelevant
subject: term
definition: a term tat describes a thing as being not important relevant to issues at hand.

name: immaterial and irrelevant
subject: tat
definition: a term tat describes a thing as being not important relevant to issues at hand.

name: imitation
subject: imitation
definition: The making of one thingIn the similitude or likeness of another; as, counterfeit coin is said to be made “in imitation”of the genuine. An imitation of a trade-mark is that which so far resembles tbegenuine trade-mark as to be likely to induce the belief that it Is genuine, whether bythe use of words or letters similar in appearance or in sound, or by any sign, device, orother means. Pen. Code N. Y. 1903,

name: kidnapping coverage
subject: package crime policy
definition: A package crime policy typically has this type of insurance coverage. Covers the dangers of a person captured against that person’s will, beyond the insured’s property, forced to enable a criminal act, such as opening a safe or telling how to do it.

name: kickoff meeting
subject: agenda
definition: Pre-launch gathering of stakeholders and prime movers of a program or project. Agenda is strategy, direction, roles, goals, and objectives.

name: kickoff meeting
subject: agenda
definition: Pre-launch gathering of stakeholders and prime movers of a program or project. Agenda is strategy, direction, roles, goals, and objectives.

name: kicker
subject: compensatin
definition: Compensatin offered to a bank so a company can use its services. Refer to equity kicker, carrot equity, and sweetner.

name: unappropriated retained earnings
subject: portion
definition: Same as retained earnings unless a portion is to be held for a certain purpose.

name: value added principal (vap)
subject: current value
definition: Finance. Current value of set of expected cash flows is equal total of all individual values.

name: want of consideration
subject: money property
definition: a term applied to a transaction where no money, property or goods were intended to pass from one party to another party.

name: want of consideration
subject: good
definition: a term applied to a transaction where no money, property or goods were intended to pass from one party to another party.

name: absentee owner
subject: absentee landlord
definition: Absentee landlord is another name for this.

name: absconding debtor
subject: person
definition: A person who owes money to another person and he runs away from his creditors or goes into hiding so he cannot be found.

name: absconding debtor
subject: person
definition: A person who owes money to another person and he runs away from his creditors or goes into hiding so he cannot be found.

name: abroachment
subject: good
definition: When goods are bought wholesale and are then sold retail but are not offered to the open market for sale.

name: abridgment of damages
subject: court
definition: Where the court will reduce the amount damages to paid that a jury has awarded to a victim. The court may deem the amount to be too high.

name: abridged accounts
subject: abbreviated account
definition: An account that does not include detailed financial information but records the transactions of a full accounting period. Abbreviated accounts may be a definition of interest.

name: backup
subject: resource
definition: 1. another resource used to make sure an activity can go on. Or a project that is done if a primary one cannot be done. 2. saving data on disk that are stored on disc or offsite. This prevents important information from being lost, stolen, or satotaged.

name: backflush costing
subject: inventory
definition: Pricing a product by using the finished result and working your way back. When inventory must be kept low this is the way costing is done. AKA backflush accounting.

name: call accounting
subject: call accounting system
definition: A Call Accounting System is a telecommunications software or hardware application that captures, records, and costs telephone usage events.

name: calendaring
subject: method
definition: A method of using rollers to compress paper during its making, to impact a finish or smoothness, it reduces the thickness and increases the density.

name: calendar spread
subject: calendar spread
definition: In finance, a calendar spread (also called a time spread or horizontal spread) is a spread trade involving the simultaneous purchase of futures or options expiring in a particular month and the sale of the same instrument expiring in another month.

name: dangerous goods declaration
subject: that cosignor
definition: A document that a cosignor makes to certify a dangerous good is in accordance with international shipping standards.

name: dan
subject: better sort
definition: Anciently the better sort of men In England had this title; so the Spanish Don. The old term of honor for men, as we now say Master or Mister. Wharton.

name: dan
subject: better sort
definition: Anciently the better sort of men In England had this title; so the Spanish Don. The old term of honor for men, as we now say Master or Mister. Wharton.

name: damnum absque injuria
subject: person
definition: Loss, hurt, or harm without injury in the legal sense, that is, without such an invasion of rights as is redressible by an action. A loss which does not give rise to an action of damages against the person causing it; as where a person blocks up the windows of a new house overlooking his land, or injures a person’s trade by setting up an establishment of the same kind in the neighborhood. Broom, Com. Law, 75; Marbury v. Madison, 1 Cranch, 164, 2 L. Ed. 60; West Virginia Transp. Co. v. Standard Oil Co., 50 W. Va. 611, 40 S. E. 591, 56 L. R. A. 804, 88 Am. St. Rep. 895; Irwin v. Askew, 74 Ga. 581; Chase v. Silverstone, 62 Me. 175, 16 Am. Rep. 419; Lumber Co. v. U. S., 69 Fed. 32

name: edictum annuum
subject: his office
definition: The annual edict or system of rules promulgated by a Roman praetorimmediately upon assuming his office, setting forth the principles by which he wouldbe guided in determining causes during his term of office. Mackeld. Rom. Law,

name: edge act bank
subject: act bank
definition: A US banking entity, owned by a state or nationallychartered BANK, with an international business scope. Edge Act banks are authorized to operate interstate branches, accept DEPOSITS from offshore sources, invest in foreign securities and projects, and grant foreign LOANS. See also INTERNATIONAL BANKING FACILITY.

name: economic capital
subject: economic capital
definition: CAPITAL resources that a company allocates internally to conduct its operations and support its RISKS (including FINANCIAL RISK and OPERATING RISK). Economic capital, which is a key measure of SOLVENCY, serves to absorb unexpected losses and allow a firm to continue its operations. Also known as MANAGEMENT CAPITAL. See also CAPITAL ALLOCATION, REGULATORY CAPITAL, RISK CAPITAL, TIER 1 CAPITAL, TIER 2 CAPITAL.

name: economic capital
subject: firm
definition: CAPITAL resources that a company allocates internally to conduct its operations and support its RISKS (including FINANCIAL RISK and OPERATING RISK). Economic capital, which is a key measure of SOLVENCY, serves to absorb unexpected losses and allow a firm to continue its operations. Also known as MANAGEMENT CAPITAL. See also CAPITAL ALLOCATION, REGULATORY CAPITAL, RISK CAPITAL, TIER 1 CAPITAL, TIER 2 CAPITAL.

name: echantillon
subject: one
definition: In French law. One of the two parts or pieces of a wooden tally.That in possession of the debtor is properly called the “tally,” the other “echantillon.”Poth. Obi. pt 4, c. 1, art. 2,

name: fail to receive
subject: situation buying dealer
definition: A situation where a buying DEALER has not received securities from the selling dealer, and will thus not make its payment. Fails are commonly used as a measure of operations-based PROCESS RISK. See also AGED FAIL, FAIL TO DELIVER.

name: fail to deliver
subject: situation sell dealer
definition: A situation where a selling DEALER has not delivered securities to the buying dealer, and will thus not receive payment. Fails are commonly used as a measure of operationsbased PROCESS RISK. See also FAIL TO RECEIVE, AGED FAIL.

name: fail
subject: latter
definition: 1. The difference between “fail” and “refuse” is that the latter involves an actof the will, while the former may be an act of inevitable necessity. Taylor v. Mason, 9Wheat. 344, 6 L. Ed. 101. See Stallings v. Thomas, 55 Ark. 320, 18 S. W. 184; TelegraphCo. v. Irvin, 27 Ind. App. 02, 59 N. E. 327; Persons v. Ilight, 4 Ga. 497.2. A person is said to “fail” when he becomes insolvent and unable to meet his obligationsas they mature. Davis v. Campbell, 3 Stew. (Ala.) 321; Mayer v. Hermann, 16 Fed. Cas. 1,242.

name: fail
subject: former
definition: 1. The difference between “fail” and “refuse” is that the latter involves an actof the will, while the former may be an act of inevitable necessity. Taylor v. Mason, 9Wheat. 344, 6 L. Ed. 101. See Stallings v. Thomas, 55 Ark. 320, 18 S. W. 184; TelegraphCo. v. Irvin, 27 Ind. App. 02, 59 N. E. 327; Persons v. Ilight, 4 Ga. 497.2. A person is said to “fail” when he becomes insolvent and unable to meet his obligationsas they mature. Davis v. Campbell, 3 Stew. (Ala.) 321; Mayer v. Hermann, 16 Fed. Cas. 1,242.

name: gapping
subject: gapping
definition: The process of deliberately mismatching ASSETS and LIABILITIES in order to take advantage of an anticipated change in INTEREST RATES. Although gapping has the potential of generating greater returns, it can also increase a firm

name: gap ratio
subject: measure
definition: Calculated as the worth of a company’s short-term investments against short-term expenses. Measures recognized profit at investment due-date.

name: gap ratio
subject: measure
definition: Calculated as the worth of a company’s short-term investments against short-term expenses. Measures recognized profit at investment due-date.

name: joint tort
subject: term wrong
definition: a term where a wrong will be shared between 2 or more people as they are responsible jointly.

name: joint executors
subject: term
definition: the term used when there is more than one executor to an estate.

name: joint committee
subject: joint committee
definition: A joint committee of a legislative body comprising two chambers is a committee consisting of representatives of each of the two houses, meeting and acting together as one committee.

name: joint ballot
subject: joint ballot
definition: In parliamentary practice, a joint ballot is an election or vote by ballot participated in by the members of both houses of a legislative assembly sitting together as one body, the result being determined by a majority of the votes cast by the joint assembly thus constituted, instead of by concurrent majorities of the two houses. See State v. Shaw, 9 S. C. 144.

name: joint ballot
subject: joint ballot
definition: In parliamentary practice, a joint ballot is an election or vote by ballot participated in by the members of both houses of a legislative assembly sitting together as one body, the result being determined by a majority of the votes cast by the joint assembly thus constituted, instead of by concurrent majorities of the two houses. See State v. Shaw, 9 S. C. 144.

name: joint
subject: bond note
definition: United; combined; undivided; done by or against two or more unitedly; shared by or between two or more.     A “joint” bond, note, or other obligation is one in which the obligors or makers (being two or more in number) bind themselves jointly but not severally, and which must therefore be prosecuted in a joint action against them all. A “joint and several” bond or note is one in which the obligors or makers bind themselves both jointly and individually to the obligee or payee, and which may be enforced either by a joint action against them all or by separate actions against any one or more at the election of the creditor.

name: joint
subject: other obligation
definition: United; combined; undivided; done by or against two or more unitedly; shared by or between two or more.     A “joint” bond, note, or other obligation is one in which the obligors or makers (being two or more in number) bind themselves jointly but not severally, and which must therefore be prosecuted in a joint action against them all. A “joint and several” bond or note is one in which the obligors or makers bind themselves both jointly and individually to the obligee or payee, and which may be enforced either by a joint action against them all or by separate actions against any one or more at the election of the creditor.

name: illusion
subject: image
definition: In medical jurisprudence. An image or Impression in the mind, excited bysome external object addressing itself to one or more of the senses, but which, insteadof corresponding with the renllty, is perverted, distorted, or wholly mistaken, the errorbeing attributable to the imagination of the observer, not to any defect in the organs ofsense. See HALLUCINATION, and see “Delusion,” under INSANITY.

name: illusion
subject: impression
definition: In medical jurisprudence. An image or Impression in the mind, excited bysome external object addressing itself to one or more of the senses, but which, insteadof corresponding with the renllty, is perverted, distorted, or wholly mistaken, the errorbeing attributable to the imagination of the observer, not to any defect in the organs ofsense. See HALLUCINATION, and see “Delusion,” under INSANITY.

name: khalsa
subject: business
definition: In Hindu law. An office of government in which the business of the revenue department was transacted uuder the Mohammedan government, and during the early period of British rule. Khalsa lauds are lands, the revenue of which is paid into the exchequer. Wharton.

name: keynesian theory
subject: john maynard keyne
definition: British economist John Maynard Keynes established this economic theory. A stable, growing economy requires active government intervention is the concept embodied by the theory.

name: keynesian theory
subject: economy
definition: British economist John Maynard Keynes established this economic theory. A stable, growing economy requires active government intervention is the concept embodied by the theory.

name: key task analysis
subject: required time
definition: Typically employed in managerial or supervisory level employee training. Determining the level of performance required, time taken, quality of outcome, and total job or project quality by the study of a set of operation(s). Also called key results analysis,

name: key ratios
subject: business analysts
definition: Business analysts evaluate a firm’s financial position and income using these financial performance measures. They are reliably indicate management competence, specifically when compared to previous periods or against a competitor’s ratios. Net income to average assets, also known as return on assets or ROA, net income to equity, also known as return on equity or ROE), net income to total investment, also known as return on investment or ROI, and net income to outstanding shares, also known as earnings per share or EPS are main examples of key ratios.

name: key ratios
subject: business analysts
definition: Business analysts evaluate a firm’s financial position and income using these financial performance measures. They are reliably indicate management competence, specifically when compared to previous periods or against a competitor’s ratios. Net income to average assets, also known as return on assets or ROA, net income to equity, also known as return on equity or ROE), net income to total investment, also known as return on investment or ROI, and net income to outstanding shares, also known as earnings per share or EPS are main examples of key ratios.

name: key punching
subject: key punching
definition: Keyboard or keypad driven computerized data entry. Prior to PCs, to issue commands or store data in the era of mini or mainframe computers, key punching was actual punching of holes in punch cards or paper tape.

name: umbrella reinsurance
subject: insurance
definition: Insurance sought to cover liabilities above and beyone primary insurance. It can also be used to fill in the cracks of primary insurance. This coverage is more broad than primary insurance.

name: umbrella reinsurance
subject: insurance
definition: Insurance sought to cover liabilities above and beyone primary insurance. It can also be used to fill in the cracks of primary insurance. This coverage is more broad than primary insurance.

name: umbrella liability coverage
subject: liability insurance
definition: Policy of liability insurance covering claims not covered or in excess of cover amount under basic policy for liability.

name: ultroneous witness
subject: volunteer witness
definition: In Scotch law. A volunteer witness; one who appears to give evidence without being called upon. 2 Alis. Crim. Pr. 303.

name: ultroneous witness
subject: one
definition: In Scotch law. A volunteer witness; one who appears to give evidence without being called upon. 2 Alis. Crim. Pr. 303.

name: valuation charge
subject: additional charge
definition: Additional charge for insurance placed on a shipper whose cargo has a greater value than he is insured to carry.

name: valuation account
subject: account
definition: Account used to offset value changes of a firm’s assets.

name: valuable consideration
subject: man
definition: The distinction between a good and a valuable consideration is that the former consists of blood, or of natural love and affection; as when a man grants an estate to a near rela- tion from motives of generosity, prudence, and natural duty; and the latter consists of such a consideration as money, marriage which is to follow, or the like, which the law esteems an equivalent given for the grant 2 Bl. Comm. 297. A valuable consideration is a thing of value parted with, or a new obligation assumed, at the time of obtaining a thing, which is a substantial compensation for that which is obtained thereby. It is also called simply “value.” Civ. Code Dak.

name: walkout strike
subject: industrial employees
definition: Industrial where employees leave work site an will not return.

name: waiver of preemptive rights
subject: investor
definition: When an investor agrees to relinquish the right to acquire new stock when issued. They must wait until the stock is on the market. Refer preemptive rights and rights issue.

name: youthful offender
subject: term
definition: This term applies to an offender who is not a juvenile but not an adult either and may get a lenient sentence, rehabilitation and the setting aside of the conviction.

name: youth
subject: word
definition: This word may include children and youth of both sexes. Nelson v. Cushlng,2 Cush. (Mass.) 519, 528.

name: youth
subject: word
definition: This word may include children and youth of both sexes. Nelson v. Cushlng,2 Cush. (Mass.) 519, 528.

name: above full-employment equilibrium
subject: occurs economy
definition: This occurs when the economy produces goods at a higher rate than normal. The level of normalcy is decided by the gross domestic product or the GDP. This causes the market to balance itself by preventing a shortcoming later.

name: abnormal variation
subject: loss
definition: An error in the system or theft that can cause significant reduction in a company’s inventory. The loss exceeds the normal allowable level.

name: abnormal return
subject: periodic return
definition: A periodic return on stocks traded in an investment portfolio should there be more or less than average returned. Also called an excess return.

name: backed currency
subject: value
definition: When currency has value has value connected to another commodity like gold.

name: backdoor listing
subject: company
definition: When an unlisted company merges with another on the list to be added to it. It is done when the company has failed to make the exchange list requirements.

name: backdating
subject: insurer
definition: When application date is after the effective date on any contract. Insurers do this deciding age younger than the actual age of the insured.

name: backdating
subject: insurer
definition: When application date is after the effective date on any contract. Insurers do this deciding age younger than the actual age of the insured.

name: back, v
subject: warrant
definition: To indorse; to sign on the back; to sign generally by way of acceptance or approval. Where a warrant issued in one county is presented to a magistrate of another county and he signs it for the purpose of making it executory in his county, he is said to “back” it. 4 Bl. Comm. 201. So an Indorser of a note or bill is colloquially said to “back” it. Seabury v. Hungerford, 2 Hill (N. Y.) 80.

name: back-to-back loan
subject: company
definition: (1) A pair of local currency LOANS between two companies, documented under a single agreement providing for the right of OFFSET, which allows the companies to onlend the local currency funds to their own subsidiaries and eliminates the need for the subsidiaries to source their own local financing. (2) A loan commitment from a BANK to a real estate developer that includes a construction loan for initial building and a permanent MORTGAGE loan for ongoing financing once the project has been developed. (1) See also PARALLEL LOAN.

name: back-end system
subject: computer
definition: A computer or computers that do calculation heavy operations for corporations.

name: back-end system
subject: computer
definition: A computer or computers that do calculation heavy operations for corporations.

name: calculus of voting
subject: calculus of voting
definition: Refers to any mathematical model which predicts voting behavior by an electorate, including such features as participation rate. A calculus of voting represents an hypothesized decision-making process.

name: cafeteria plan
subject: cafeteria plan
definition: A cafeteria plan is a type of employee benefit plan offered in the United States pursuant to Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code. Its name comes from the earliest such plans that allowed employees to choose between different types of benefits, similar to a cafeteria.

name: damages
subject: pecuniary compensation
definition: A pecuniary compensation or indemnity, which may be recovered in the courts by any person who has suffered loss, detriment, or injury, whether to his person, property, or rights, through the unlawful act or omission or negligence of another. Scott v. Donald, 105 U. S. 58, 17 Sup. Ct. 205, 41 L. Ed. 032; Crane v. Peer, 43 N. J. Eq. 553, 4 Atl. 72; Cincinnati v. Hafer, 49 Ohio St. 00, 30 N. E. 197; Wainscott v. Loan Ass’n, 98 Cal. 253, 33 Pac. 8S; Carvill v. Jacks, 43 Ark. 449; Collins v. Railroad Co., 9 Heisk. (Tenn.) 850; New York v. Lord, 17 Wend. (N. Y.) 293; O’Connor v. Dils, 43 W. Va. 54, 20 S. E. 354. A sum of money assessed by a jury, on finding for the plaintiff or successful party in an action, as a compensation for the injury done him by the opposite party. 2 Bl.Comm. 438; Co. Litt. 257a; 2 Tidd, Pr. 869, S70. Every person who suffers detriment from the unlawful act or omission of another may recover from the person in fault a compensation therefor in money, which is called “damages.” Civ. Code Cal.

subject: pecuniary compensation

name: ebdomadarius
subject: officer
definition: In ecclesiastical law. An officer in cathedral churches whosupervised the regular performance of divine service, and prescribed the particularduties of each person in the choir.

name: treaty reinsurance
subject: primary insurer
definition: When the primary insurer agrees to give up additional portions of risk to a reinsurer. The primary insurer is guaranteed to be covered but it cannot claim the potentionally profitable full share on its portfolio. Refer to facultative reinsurance, quota sh

name: facultative reinsurance
subject: insurer
definition: When the insurer decides the risk that a policy should cover. The risk left over is shared with with another insurer. Refer to treaty reinsurance.

name: facultative obligatory treaty
subject: hybrid
definition: A hybrid of FACULTATIVE REINSURANCE and TREATY REINSURANCE where the CEDING INSURER can choose to assign certain RISKS to the REINSURER, who is then required to accept them.

name: facts in issue
subject: which defendant
definition: These are the facts that a plaintiff will base his claim on or which the defendant denies the claim on.

name: factory
subject: term
definition: In Englisli law. The term includes all buildings and premises wherein, orwithin the close or curtilage of which, steam, water, or any mechanical power is used tomove or work any machinery employed in preparing, manufacturing, or finishing cotton,wool, hair, silk, flax, hemp, jute, or tow. So defined by the statute 7 Vict. c. 15,

name: factory
subject: term
definition: In Englisli law. The term includes all buildings and premises wherein, orwithin the close or curtilage of which, steam, water, or any mechanical power is used tomove or work any machinery employed in preparing, manufacturing, or finishing cotton,wool, hair, silk, flax, hemp, jute, or tow. subject: steam water
definition: In Englisli law. The term includes all buildings and premises wherein, orwithin the close or curtilage of which, steam, water, or any mechanical power is used tomove or work any machinery employed in preparing, manufacturing, or finishing cotton,wool, hair, silk, flax, hemp, jute, or tow. So defined by the statute 7 Vict. c. 15,

So defined by the statute 7 Vict. c. 15,

So defined by the statute 7 Vict. c. 15,
